section.title: Gist of Reflections and Vertical Stretches

subsection.title: Reflections
subsection.p: Thinking again of function notation as language, we know that the notation f(x) indicates that there is an input called x and an output called f(x). Therefore, by replacing x with -x we are using the opposite opposite of the input.
Likewise, if we replace f(x) with -f(x), we are referring to the opposite of the output.

From a graphical standpoint, both of the transformations -f(x) and f(-x) represent reflections of a graph:
y = -f(x)
reflects y = f(x) over the horizontal-axis
y = f(-x)
reflects y = f(x) over the vertical-axis

subsection.p: One use of the transformation -f(x) is in redefining a variable from positive-to-negative, or vice versa, as shown in the example below.

statement.p:
When deep sea divers swim back to the surface of the water after a dive, they must do so slowly. If a diver ascends too quickly, she may experience decompression sickness. In order to prevent this, divers must ascend at a rate slower than
33 .

Suppose a diver begins at a depth of
100
and ascends at a rate of
30 .

If we wanted to represent the diver's depth below the water as a function of time, we could write:
D = f(t) = 100 - 30t

Alternatively, we could have written a function for the diver's altitude as a function of time. In this case, the diver's altitude when below the water would be negative, so our function would be:
A = g(t) = -100 + 30t
Notice that the altitude is the opposite of the depth here, so our function g(t) is equal to -f(t).

subsection.title: Vertical Stretches and Compressions
subsection.p:
In addition to reflecting a function, we can also stretch vertical stretch functionvertical stretch or compress vertical compression functionvertical compression a function vertically by multiplying the output by a constant number a.
If a > 1
The transformation y = a\cdot f(x) will vertically stretch the graph of y = f(x) by a factor of a.
If 0 < a < 1
The transformation y = a\cdot f(x) will vertically compress the graph of y = f(x) by a factor of a.

example.p:
For the function
f(x) = x^2 - 1 , describe the transformations 3f(x) and \frac{1}{2}f(x).

For the first transformation, we have:
3f(x) \amp= 3(x^2 - 1) \amp= 3x^2 - 3
This is just like f(x) = x^2 - 1, but all of the output values have been multiplied by 3.
Since the output values were all multiplied by 3, this would make all of the y-coordinates of the points 3 times as far from zero (either positive or negative).
Since the output values were all multiplied by \frac{1}{2}, this would make all of the y values of the points only half as far from zero (either positive or negative).

paragraphs.title: Even and Odd Functions
paragraphs.p: You will notice that some functions, after being reflected over the vertical axis, remain the same as they began. That is, the transformation f(-x) is the same as the original function f(x).

If the graph of a function is unchanged after reflecting it over the vertical axis, then we say the function is even. even function functioneven In function notation, a function is called even if:
f(-x) = f(x)
Geometrically, an even function is symmetric over the vertical axis.

subsection.p:
On the other hand, we may try to reflect a function over the vertical axis, and find that this is the same as reflecting it over the horizontal axis. In function notation, this would mean that:
f(-x) = -f(x)
If f(-x) = -f(x), then we say f is an odd odd function functionodd function. Geometrically, an odd function is symmetric about the origin.
